head.title: 'Zero Emission' Car Still Fouls the Planet

hedline.hl1: 'Zero Emission' Car Still Fouls the Planet

abstract.p: Roland Hwang letter on Nov 2 article on Honda's new zero-level-emissions vehicle; drawing (S)

block.p: ''Hybrid Effort by Honda to Curb Exhaust Pollution'' (Automobiles, Nov. 2) did a disservice to electric vehicles in reporting that Honda's new zero-level-emissions vehicle is supposed to have equivalent emissions to the plants generating power for electric vehicles. That comparison ignores substantial amounts of pollution that gasoline vehicles directly or indirectly emit: increases of tailpipe emissions over time, evaporation of fuel from the vehicle and from gasoline refining and delivery to the market.

''Hybrid Effort by Honda to Curb Exhaust Pollution'' (Automobiles, Nov. 2) did a disservice to electric vehicles in reporting that Honda's new zero-level-emissions vehicle is supposed to have equivalent emissions to the plants generating power for electric vehicles. That comparison ignores substantial amounts of pollution that gasoline vehicles directly or indirectly emit: increases of tailpipe emissions over time, evaporation of fuel from the vehicle and from gasoline refining and delivery to the market.

When these factors are taken into account, pollution from Honda's new vehicle rises 70 times for hydrocarbons and 5 times for nitrogen oxides over its stated pollution levels. Honda's new vehicle also does nothing to reduce emissions of carbon dioxide, the primary global warming gas.
Although Honda's technology can help clean up our gasoline vehicles, this technology does not deliver the same emissions benefits as electric vehicles.
The writer is dir., transportation program, Union of Concerned Scientists.
